title: Definition of Data Validity
text: Data validity is a quality dimension where the values of a data field share the same format, type, or range as dictated by business rules or system constraints. For instance, a date field should contain valid date values.

title: Definition of Data Completeness
text: Data completeness refers to the absence of data gaps. It means the dataset contains all the required data points without missing values.

title: Why 'Completeness' is Incorrect
text: The problem does not mention any missing data. It addresses a formatting error rather than an absence of values.

title: Definition of Data Uniqueness
text: Data uniqueness checks whether all data entries are distinct within a dataset—a crucial requirement, particularly in databases requiring exclusive identifiers like social security numbers.

title: Why 'Uniqueness' is Incorrect
text: Here, there's no indication of duplicate data. The issue lies with the record's content, not its distinctness from other records.

title: Definition of Data Consistency
text: Data consistency ensures uniformity, such that aligned information expressed across different data sets or different parts of the same dataset presents no contradictions.

title: Why 'Consistency' is Incorrect
text: There's no mentioning of data correlation errors within the dataset or between datasets. The issue focuses on a single field's value format.

title: Explanation for Correctness of 'Validity'
text: The birth date '4/3/2200' is erroneous as it's implausible to have this far future birth year for a customer. Thus, it relates to the validity dimension by having a value outside the acceptable range or format.
